sec.div: Beliefs, Perceived Risk, Trust, and Responses to Climate Change
sec.p: The VBN’s environmentally oriented synthesis of a number of other behavioral models (e.g., the theory of planned behavior [ Ajzen, 1991]) has proved useful in conceptualizing and analyzing the determinants of pro-environmental behavior ( Dietz et al., 2005). We look to the VBN literature, particularly that which has focused on public response to climate change, as a reference and guide to the development of a conceptual framework specific to our research questions about the relationships between trust in agents of influence, beliefs about climate change, perceived risk, and support for adaptive and mitigative responses in agriculture.
